subject: FW: Hello All,
msgSnippet: ... From: Paige Gabhart [mailto:pgabhart@sbcglobal.net] Sent: Saturday, October 22, 2005 5:28 PM To: sensitivemedia Subject: RE: Hello All, John: I have been
messageBody:
-----Original Message-----
From: Paige Gabhart [mailto:pgabhart@...]
Sent: Saturday, October 22, 2005 5:28 PM
To: 'sensitivemedia'
Subject: RE: Hello All,

John:

I have been using Quikscript (QS) for about 30 years. I use it on a daily
basis to take notes. I also use it if I don't want someone else to be able
to read what I'm writing. Of course, this use as a "code" would be lost if
we are able to reach a significant number of people as we would like to. I
used it to take notes when in school when the professor got to talking too
fast for me to get in down in traditional orthography (TO).

Others will have to answer as to how they use QS in their daily lives.

I agree with you that the appearance of QS is quite appealing and that
attracted me to it as well. I particularly like the use of the half-letters
in Senior QS as I feel they contribute to visual appeal and distinctive word
shapes that make word recognition easier.

Regarding the use of QS as a form of shorthand: my understanding is that
shorthand is designed for making a record of speech spoken at conversational
speeds. That requirement means that proficient shorthand writers tend to
develop numerous abbreviations so that it is somewhat indecipherable even to
others who know that form of shorthand (Pitman, Gregg, etc.) In addition,
shorthands were specifically designed to be handwritten and really were not
suitable for printing. QS, on the other hand, although it is excellent for
handwriting, could also be printed by casting the letters in metal type
using traditional printing methods. Now with computer fonts, QS has been
brought into the computer age.

I would still like to see the development of an attractive QS font that
permits easy use of the half-letters although some members believe
half-letters should be restricted to handwriting.

Good luck with QS and welcome as a new member.

Paige

-----Original Message-----
From: sensitivemedia [mailto:sensitivemedia@...]
Sent: Saturday, October 22, 2005 1:15 PM
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Hello All,

Hi,

I have just run across this interesting method of writing and reading
English, and I must say it's fascinating. I haven't yet had a chance
to look at all the messages on the board, but I was curious to know
whether people use this in their day to day life, and if it is a
viable alternative to shorthand. One of the things that attracted me
to the Second Shaw alphabet was that it is visually (to me) so much
more beautiful than most of the shorthand squiggles.

Another website is using the King Plus font. Could anyone explain to
me the difference between this font and the Kingsley? Which font is
preferred by you cogniscenti?


The QS converter program is very clever. My congratulations to the
author.

Best Regards,
John
